dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Goldman Sachs just put out a note with the headline 'Soaring IOC Reserves: A Surging Advantage'.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Goldman Sachs just put out a note with the headline 'Soaring I O C Reserves: A Surging Advantage'.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Citi, an investment bank, noted the industry-wide decline of reserves in a research note published last week under the headline: Falling IOC Reserves A Looming Challenge.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh yeah, I saw that. They're saying the average reserve life for the majors is now, uh, 15.5 years? That's up like 25% since 2015.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh yeah, I saw that. They're saying the average reserve life for the majors is now, uh, fifteen point five years? That's up like twenty five percent since twenty fifteen.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Since 2015 the average reserves of the oil majors has fallen by 25% to now stand at less than 10 years of annual production. The IOC average of 9.5 years is now 25% below where the industry was prior to the oil price collapse in 2015.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And they're arguing that investors actually see that growth as a negative now, which is a huge shift.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And they're arguing that investors actually see that growth as a negative now, which is a huge shift.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Reserves in the ground is a critical measure of an oil company with a decline seen as a negative by investors.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, because reserves in the ground are a secondary metric. It's all about cash flow and transition strategy these days.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, because reserves in the ground are a secondary metric. It's all about cash flow and transition strategy these days.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: There is no bypassing this relationship between reserves and earnings, hence we think analysis of reserves trends is a highly important indicator of the health of a business, Citi said.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: They mentioned that line from an executive—'green pays for black.' Oil and gas cash flow is funding the shift to renewables.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: They mentioned that line from an executive-'green pays for black.' Oil and gas cash flow is funding the shift to renewables.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the recent words of one IOC chief executive black pays for green a reference to the 80% of CFFO (cash flow from operations) that is generated from oil and gas activities, and likely to still be more than 70% by 2030, Citi said.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But they also predict that by 2030, that contribution from oil and gas could be close to zero. So these reserves give them a runway.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But they also predict that by twenty thirty, that contribution from oil and gas could be close to zero. So these reserves give them a runway.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the recent words of one IOC chief executive black pays for green a reference to the 80% of CFFO (cash flow from operations) that is generated from oil and gas activities, and likely to still be more than 70% by 2030, Citi said.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's interesting how they split the companies into two groups. One cluster around 7.5 years—like BP, Chevron, ExxonMobil.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's interesting how they split the companies into two groups. One cluster around seven point five years-like B P, Chevron, ExxonMobil.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Citi said there were two clear groups forming across the oil sector with six IOCs tightly grouped around reserve life of around 10.5 years. They are: Total, BP, Chevron, ENI, ConocoPhillips and ExxonMobil.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And then you've got Shell, Equinor, Repsol with reserves around 20 years. That's a massive gap in strategy right there.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then you've got Shell, Equinor, Repsol with reserves around twenty years. That's a massive gap in strategy right there.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: There are three IOCs in another group (Repsol, Equinor and Shell) which have reserves around eight years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Goldman's basically saying, don't judge these companies on reserves anymore. It doesn't correlate to earnings or health.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Goldman's basically saying, don't judge these companies on reserves anymore. It doesn't correlate to earnings or health.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: There is no bypassing this relationship between reserves and earnings, hence we think analysis of reserves trends is a highly important indicator of the health of a business, Citi said.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which is kind of wild when you think about how obsessed Wall Street used to be with reserve replacement ratios.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is kind of wild when you think about how obsessed Wall Street used to be with reserve replacement ratios.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. The whole narrative has flipped. Now it's about how you manage the decline and pivot.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. The whole narrative has flipped. Now it's about how you manage the decline and pivot.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So investors want a surplus of oil reserves? As a best-case scenario? That feels counterintuitive but makes sense for the transition.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So investors want a surplus of oil reserves? As a best-case scenario? That feels counterintuitive but makes sense for the transition.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Reserves in the ground is a critical measure of an oil company with a decline seen as a negative by investors. The worst interpretation of falling reserves is that it might be an existential threat to the long-term survival of an oil company.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it gives them time and capital to figure out the next thing without panicking.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it gives them time and capital to figure out the next thing without panicking.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Hard to imagine ExxonMobil with only 7.5 years of reserves left, though. They used to be the gold standard for long-life assets.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hard to imagine ExxonMobil with only seven point five years of reserves left, though. They used to be the gold standard for long-life assets.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Citi said there were two clear groups forming across the oil sector with six IOCs tightly grouped around reserve life of around 10.5 years. They are: Total, BP, Chevron, ENI, ConocoPhillips and ExxonMobil.

artist_script:
Goldman Sachs' latest research note on soaring IOC reserves.
HostA: Goldman Sachs just put out a note with the headline 'Soaring IOC Reserves: A Surging Advantage'.
HostB: Oh yeah, I saw that. They're saying the average reserve life for the majors is now, uh, 15.5 years? That's up like 25% since 2015.
HostA: Exactly. And they’re arguing that investors actually see that growth as a negative now, which is a huge shift.
HostB: Right, because reserves in the ground are a secondary metric. It’s all about cash flow and transition strategy these days.
HostA: They mentioned that line from an executive—'green pays for black.' Oil and gas cash flow is funding the shift to renewables.
HostB: But they also predict that by 2030, that contribution from oil and gas could be close to zero. So these reserves give them a runway.
HostA: It's interesting how they split the companies into two groups. One cluster around 7.5 years—like BP, Chevron, ExxonMobil.
HostB: And then you've got Shell, Equinor, Repsol with reserves around 20 years. That's a massive gap in strategy right there.
HostA: Goldman’s basically saying, don't judge these companies on reserves anymore. It doesn't correlate to earnings or health.
HostB: Which is kind of wild when you think about how obsessed Wall Street used to be with reserve replacement ratios.
HostA: Totally. The whole narrative has flipped. Now it's about how you manage the decline and pivot.
HostB: So investors want a surplus of oil reserves? As a best-case scenario? That feels counterintuitive but makes sense for the transition.
HostA: Yeah, it gives them time and capital to figure out the next thing without panicking.
HostB: Hard to imagine ExxonMobil with only 7.5 years of reserves left, though. They used to be the gold standard for long-life assets.
HostA: Times are changing, fast.
